head.citation-title: Technical note: Pilot study of types of casualty crashes experienced by tourists in a southeast asian destination
head.abstracts: Increased awareness of the details of road accidents involving foreign tourists may lead to a reduction in the number of injuries, protection of the tourists' health, and preservation of the quality of their tourism experiences. This study investigated the type of road casualty accidents resulting mostly in the Outpatient Department attention to surgical dressings and sutures and experienced by British, German, and American tourists in one tourist location in South-East Asia, based on a review of the Injury Surveillance Form of the local hospital from 1999 to 2007. It found that the majority of accidents involved motorcycles and males, and that foreign patients admitted to hospital due to road traffic injuries were 2.64 (American), 4.85 (British), and 5.00 (German) percent of the total number of foreign patient admissions from the respective countries. The study recommends that a full database be systematically maintained by concerned organizations in tourist destinations to accurately reveal information about risk factors of casualty crashes for foreign tourists and to assist in future plans for appropriate prevention.
